  5. Under "General Settings", ensure the Host Name is the API endpoint hostname of your S/4HANA tenant (e.g., myXXXXXX-api.s4hana.cloud.sap).

  6. Under "Users for Outbound Communication", click "+".

  7. Select "Authentication Method" as "User ID and Password".

  8. Enter the User Name of the Communication User you created in Step 1.

  9. Enter the Password for this user.

  10. Click "Create".

  11. Click "Save".

Step 3: Create Communication Arrangements (Two are Needed!)

This is the crucial part for calling an API within the same system. You need two arrangements based on SAP_COM_0008:

  • One to define how external systems (or your system acting as an external caller) can call inbound to the API.

  • One to define how your system is configured to call outbound to the API endpoint.

Arrangement 1: Inbound Configuration (Defines how to call IN)

This arrangement is necessary for the API endpoint to be active and reachable, and it defines the user and authentication for incoming calls.

  1. Open the "Communication Arrangements" app.

  2. Click "New".

  3. Select the Communication Scenario: SAP_COM_0008 (Business Partner, Customer, and Supplier Integration).

  4. Enter an Arrangement Name (e.g., SAP_COM_0008_INBOUND).

  5. Click "Create".

  6. In the arrangement details:

    • Under "Communication System", select the Communication System you created in Step 2 (e.g., MY_S4_TENANT_API).

    • Under "Inbound Communication":

      • Ensure the User Name is the Communication User you created in Step 1.

      • Set the Authentication Method to "User ID and Password".

      • Review the Inbound Services list. You should see the "Business Partner (A2X)" OData service listed with its Service URL and Service ID (API_BUSINESS_PARTNER).

    • Under "Outbound Communication": This section is less critical for this specific arrangement's purpose.

  7. Click "Save".

  8. Ensure the Status is "Active".

Arrangement 2: Outbound Configuration (Defines how to call OUT)

This arrangement defines the specific configuration used by cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement in your ABAP code to make an outbound call to the API.

  1. Open the "Communication Arrangements" app again.

  2. Click "New".

  3. Choose Newly created Communication Scenario ( note : Create New Communication Scenario: ZZZXXXXYY and provide the Business Partner API as Outbound Service over there ). 

     

  4. Enter a different Arrangement Name (e.g., SAP_COM_0008_OUTBOUND).

  5. Click "Create".

  6. In the arrangement details:

    • Under "Communication System", select the same Communication System you used for the first arrangement (e.g., MY_S4_TENANT_API).

    • Under "Inbound Communication": This section is not the primary focus here.

    • Under "Outbound Communication":

      • Ensure the User Name is the same Communication User you created in Step 1.

      • Set the Authentication Method to "User ID and Password".

      • Crucially, find the entry for the Service ID API_BUSINESS_PARTNER. This entry must exist and be configured with the correct URL (which should be automatically populated based on the scenario and system) and the authentication method.

  7. Click "Save".

  8. Ensure the Status is "Active".

Why the Same Username and Password are Crucial for Basic Authentication:

When your ABAP code initiates the outbound call using the second Communication Arrangement, the system uses the Communication User and password configured in that arrangement's Outbound Communication section for the specified service ID. This user and password are sent as basic authentication credentials to the target endpoint.

Since the target endpoint is the same S/4HANA tenant's API, and that endpoint is configured to accept inbound calls using the first Communication Arrangement, the credentials sent by the outbound call are validated against the user configured for inbound calls in the first arrangement.

Therefore, for basic authentication to succeed in this "calling within the same system" scenario, the Communication User and password configured for Outbound Communication in the second arrangement must match the Communication User and password configured for Inbound Communication in the first arrangement. If they differ, the inbound authentication check will fail, leading to errors (like the SAML redirection ).

ABAP Code to Call the API

Once the Communication Arrangements are set up, your ABAP code in Embedded Steampunk can use the standard OData client proxy or HTTP client framework to call the API.

You would typically use cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement with the details of your outbound-focused Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0008, MY_S4_TENANT_API, API_BUSINESS_PARTNER) to get the HTTP destination and then create an HTTP client or OData client proxy.

 

 

DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_web_http_client,
        lo_req         TYPE REF TO if_web_http_request,
        lo_resp        TYPE REF TO if_web_http_response,
        lv_status      TYPE i,
        lv_response    TYPE string.

  TRY.
      "1. Create an HTTP destination using your communication arrangement.
      DATA(lo_destination) = cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement(
           comm_scenario  = ' '   " The communication scenario defined in the system
           comm_system_id = ' '                    " For same S/4HANA Public Cloud system
           service_id     = ' ' ).  " Service ID as configured (Outbound Service Name )

      "2. Create the HTTP client – basic auth is handled by the arrangement.
      lo_http_client = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination( lo_destination ).

      "3. Prepare HTTP headers.
      lo_req = lo_http_client->get_http_request( ).
      lo_req->set_header_fields( VALUE #(
           ( name = 'Accept'      value = 'application/json' )
           ( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ) ) ).

lo_req->set_uri_path( '/A_BusinessPartner(''0010000000'')' ).

      "6. Execute the GET request using the client, passing the method.
      lo_resp = lo_http_client->execute(
                  i_method = if_web_http_client=>get ).
  
      data(lv_status1) = lo_resp->get_status( ).
      lv_response = lo_resp->get_text( ).

      IF lv_status = 200.
      ELSE.
      ENDIF.

    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_root).

  ENDTRY.

  IF lo_http_client IS BOUND.
    lo_http_client->close( ).
  ENDIF.

 

Conclusion

Calling public APIs within Embedded Steampunk requires careful configuration of Communication Arrangements and Communication Systems. While the concept is similar to calling external APIs, calling an API hosted within the same tenant necessitates understanding the interplay between inbound and outbound configurations. By creating two Communication Arrangements based on the same scenario and system, and ensuring the same Communication User with basic authentication is configured for both inbound and outbound communication for the relevant service, you can successfully enable your on-stack ABAP extensions to interact with public APIs like the Business Partner API. This setup ensures that the system correctly resolves the destination and authenticates the call using the configured basic authentication credentials.

entry.title: Building and Publishing External APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public: From ADT to Postman
entry.content:
Overview

This guide explains how to create and expose a custom external API using the Developer Extensibility approach in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition. The process involves creating a custom business object, implementing its behavior, and publishing it as a service accessible to external systems.

 

Prerequisites

  • Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition with developer extensibility enabled.
  • ABAP Development Tools (ADT) installed in Eclipse.
  • Business role SAP_BR_DEVELOPER assigned.
  • A development package created in the ABAP environment.

Step-by-Step Guide

Create a Custom Database Table: This is the foundational data structure where your application’s data will be stored. It represents the physical storage in the system.

  • In ADT, create a new database table (e.g., ZTODO_LIST).
  • Define required fields and activate the table.

Create a Root CDS View (Interface View): The root CDS view defines the business object’s main entity (the root node) and provides an abstraction over the database table. It enables the use of annotations and is required to define the behavior and expose data services.

  • Right-click your package > New > Data Definition.
  • Name it (e.g., Z_I_TODO_LIST).
  • Use defines root view syntax to expose your database table.
  • Annotate with @ObjectModel: and activate the view.

Create Behavior Definition with Managed Implementation: The behavior definition governs how the data can be interacted with (Create, Read, Update, Delete - CRUD). Using managed implementation reduces manual coding and allows SAP to handle the data persistence layer automatically.

  • Right-click on the CDS view > New Behavior Definition.
  • Mapping the CDS Fields with Custom table.

Create a Projection View: The projection view exposes only the fields and structure you want available to the external world via the API. It acts as the public API interface layered over the root CDS view and enables additional annotations like UI or access control.

  • Right-click > New > Data Definition.
  • Use define root view entity as projection

Create behavior definition for your Projection View: Determines what operations (Create, Update, Delete, Action, etc.) are exposed to consumers of the API.

Define a Service Definition: The service definition tells SAP which projection view (and hence, which data and operations) to expose as a service. This is a required layer before service binding can be created.

  • Right-click > New > Service Definition.

Create a Service Binding: The binding connects the service definition to a specific protocol (e.g., OData V4) and exposes the service endpoint URL.
It also allows you to publish the service so it's available in the system catalog.

  • Right-click > New > Service Binding.
  • Choose OData V4 as the binding type.
  • Name and activate the binding.
  • Click Publish to make it available.

Create a Communication Scenario: The communication scenario defines the APIs and authorizations needed for external communication. It acts as a container that external systems will use to discover and authenticate with your custom service.

  • In ADT, create a communication scenario.
  • Add your service binding.
  • Define inbound service, I/O structure, and authorization.
  • Activate and publish it.

Configure Communication Arrangement in SAP Fiori:  The communication arrangement ties the communication scenario to an actual communication system and user credentials.

Prerequisites:

  1. Create a New Communication User:
    1. Go to the Fiori Launchpad.
    2. Search for or open "Maintain Communication Users" app.
    3. Click on "New".
    4. Fill in the required fields
    5. Save the user.
  2. Create a Communication System:
    1. Go to your SAP Fiori Launchpad.
    2. Search for and open "Communication Systems".
    3. Users for Inbound Communication
    4. Click "New".
    5. Fill Communication Users (technical credentials).
    6. Save.
  • Open “Communication Arrangements” app in SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  • Create a new arrangement using your communication scenario.
  • Set communication system, user, and authentication method.
  • Save to generate the external API URL.

 

Test - Postman:

Conclusion

Building an external API in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition) using Developer Extensibility gives developers the tools to connect seamlessly with external systems — securely, efficiently, and in line with SAP best practices. By following a structured, standards-compliant process, you create scalable, flexible APIs that support modern integration needs, third-party tools, and future innovations in the cloud landscape.

And hey — if your API doesn’t work the first time... don’t panic. Just turn it off, activate it again, and pretend it was a test all along. 😅

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Setting Up Custom Fields in Work Center Formula Parameters
entry.content:
Hello All,

Welcome to my blog!!

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, customizing fields and formulas in manufacturing processes can greatly enhance flexibility and precision. This blog post walks you through the steps to create and map custom fields to Work Center Formula Parameters, enabling you to define custom calculations tailored to your business requirements. Whether you’re configuring manufacturing master data or refining routing operations, this guide provides a clear, step-by-step approach to ensure a smooth setup.

  • Access Fiori app ‘Custom Fields’ > Click ‘+’ icon to create a custom field. In the New Field popup, set the Business Context to ‘Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation (PP_BILLOFOPERATIONS_OPERATION) and the field type to ‘Quantity with Unit’ as no other Business context or field types are supported for WorkCentre formula parameters. Once required data entered, click Create and Edit.

  • On the Custom Field screen, under the General Information tab, take note of the Field Component Name ending with the suffix ‘_PPO’, as this will be used to map the custom field to a parameter.

  • On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services.

  • Enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant APIs.

  • Enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant Business Scenario. Enable Routing to Production order on Operation level for Discrete Manufacturing, Master Recipe to Process Order on Operation Level for Process Manufacturing and Shop Floor Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for Complex Manufacturing scenarios.

  • Enable the custom field’s usage for the required SOAP APIs

  • After entering all the necessary information, Save and Publish the custom field. Once saved, you’ll notice two entries: one for the Bill of Operations Operation business context and another for the Order Operation business context, where the custom field will be visible.

  • Once the custom field is published, you can view the newly created field at Routing Operation level under Custom Fields section.

  • Navigate to Configuration path Manufacturing and Quality > Manufacturing Master Data > Common Settings for Work Center and Resource > Define Parameters

  • Create the Work Center Formula Parameter with origin 8 (Custom Field from Operation). Fill in all the necessary data, leaving the ‘Field Name’ field blank.

  • Once the parameter is defined, map the newly created custom field to Workcenter formula parameter via Manufacturing and Quality > Manufacturing Master Data > Routings > Routing > Mapping custom Tasklist operation Fields to Work Center Formula Parameters.

  • Create New Entries by adding the parameter name that is created in Step (10) and the Field component name recorded in step (2)

  • Once mapping completed, navigate to the configuration path Manufacturing and Quality > Manufacturing Master Data > Work Centers > Work Center > Define Formulas for Work Centers

  • Define the formula according to business requirements, using the parameter mapped to the custom field.

By following these steps, you can effectively configure custom fields and map them to Work Center Formula Parameters in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This allows for greater customization and precision in your manufacturing operations, enabling you to define formulas that align perfectly with your business needs. With the right setup, you can unlock the full potential of SAP’s flexible manufacturing framework and enhance your operational efficiency.

For more details with a business scenario, please refer https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/controlling-and-scheduling-the-production-using-the-work-center-formula/ba-p/14157931

Hope you find it informative and Happy Learning!!

entry.title: Scheduling Background Jobs in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Step 1: Create the ABAP Class with Required Interfaces

You’ll start by creating a class that contains the logic to be executed in the background.

Interfaces Implemented:

  • IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN: Allows testing the class directly in ADT.
  • IF_APJ_DT_EXEC_OBJECT: Defines job metadata and input parameters.
  • IF_APJ_RT_EXEC_OBJECT: Contains the actual logic to be executed in the background job.

Your class might look like this:

CLASS zcl_insert_sample_data DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES: if_oo_adt_classrun,
                if_apj_dt_exec_object,
                if_apj_rt_exec_object.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS: insert_sample_data.
ENDCLASS.
METHOD if_apj_rt_exec_object~execute.
* " This is the method that will be called by the background job
DATA: application_log           TYPE REF TO if_bali_log,
          application_log_free_text TYPE REF TO if_bali_free_text_setter.
   TRY.
   insert_sample_data( ).
application_log = cl_bali_log=>create_with_header(
                               header = cl_bali_header_setter=>create( object = 'XYZ' " Use your custom log object/subobject
                                                                       subobject = 'INSERT' ) ).
        application_log_free_text = cl_bali_free_text_setter=>create(
                                        severity = if_bali_constants=>c_severity_information " Or c_severity_success
                                        text     = 'Sample data inserted successfully.' ).

        application_log->add_item( item = application_log_free_text ).
        cl_bali_log_db=>get_instance( )->save_log(
            log                        = application_log
            assign_to_current_appl_job = abap_true  ).

      CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_error).
        " Log the error message to the Application Log
*        application_log = cl_bali_log=>create_with_header(
*                               header = cl_bali_header_setter=>create( object = 'ZSAMPLE_DATA'
*                                                                       subobject = 'INSERT' ) ).
*        application_log_free_text = cl_bali_free_text_setter=>create(
*                                        severity = if_bali_constants=>c_severity_error
*                                        text     = |Error inserting data: { lx_error->get_text( ) }| ).
*
*        application_log->add_item( item = application_log_free_text ).
*        cl_bali_log_db=>get_instance( )->save_log(
*            log                        = application_log
*            assign_to_current_appl_job = abap_true  ).

        " Re-raise the exception to signal job failure to the framework
*        RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE cx_apj_rt_exec_object
*          EXPORTING
*            previous = lx_error.

    ENDTRY.

This class inserts sample data into a custom table and logs the result using CL_BALI_LOG.

📘 Step 2: Create a Job Catalog Entry in ADT

Once your class is ready, the next step is to register it in the Job Catalog using ADT.

How to do it:

  1. In ADT, go to the Project Explorer.
  2. Right-click on your package → New → Other → ABAP Repository Object.
  3. Search for Job Catalog Entry.
  4. Provide:
    • Catalog ID: e.g., ZZ1_INSER_DATA
    • Description: e.g., Insert Sample Titles
    • Execution Class: ZCL_INSERT_SAMPLE_DATA
  5. Save and activate.

 

This step makes your class available for job templates.

🧾 Step 3: Create a Job Template in ADT

Now, create a Job Template based on the catalog entry.

Steps:

  1. In ADT, right-click your package → New → Other → ABAP Repository Object.
  2. Search for Job Template.
  3. Provide:
    • Template ID: ZZ1_JOB
    • Description: Insert Sample Titles
    • Job Catalog Entry: ZZ1_INSER_DATA
  4. If your class uses parameters, map them here.
  5. Save and activate.

 

This template will be used in the Fiori app to schedule the job.

🌐 Step 4: Create an Application Job Template in Fiori

Now switch to the Fiori Launchpad.

Steps:

  1. Open the "Manage Application Job Templates" app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Fill in:
    • Template Name: e.g., Insert Sample Titles
    • Job Template ID: ZZ1_JOB (from ADT)
    • Job Catalog ID: ZZ1_INSER_DATA
  4. Save and activate.

This step makes the job template available for end users.

Step 5: Schedule the Job in Fiori

Finally, schedule the job using the Fiori app.

Steps:

  1. Open the "Schedule Application Jobs" app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Select your Application Job Template.
  4. Set:
    • Start Time: Immediate or scheduled
    • Recurrence: One-time or recurring
  5. Click Schedule.

🧾 Application Logging

Your class uses CL_BALI_LOG to write messages to the application log. This is essential for monitoring and debugging.

Benefits:

  • Structured logging with severity levels.
  • Integration with job monitoring tools.
  • Easy to trace job execution history.

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: How to add a custom field to a specific Fiori UI section
entry.content:
Have you ever created a key user custom field and wanted to display it in a standard SAP Fiori UI, but didn't know which OData service entity to enable to make the field available in the field list offered by Fiori Runtime Adaptation?

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. It explains how you can find out the respective OData service entity manually (called Variant 1: Manual way). It also explains a much simpler alternative how to enable the OData service entity for the given field using the integration between Fiori Runtime Adaptation and the key user custom field tool (called Variant 2: Automatic way).

Variant 1: Manual way

The first step is to identify which OData service entity provides the data for the UI section in the Fiori UI of the SAP standard application. Once you have this information, you can enable the custom field in the Custom Fields app for the specified OData service entity. This action makes the custom field available in the list of fields within Fiori Runtime Adaptation.

Let’s assume that you created a custom field named “Priority” on the business context SD_SALESDOC, and you want to expose this custom field in the Fiori app Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 (Fiori app ID F3893). You want to place the field in the “Basic Data” section of the “General Information” section of the Sales Order UI (the location is marked with a red cross within the screenshot).

You want to place the custom field here

First, you need to find out which OData service entity provides the data for the UI section where you want to place the field.
You can find this out by adhering to the following steps:

  1. Open the Fiori app Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and navigate to the respective screen within this UI (in our case, it’s the detail screen of the sales order)
  2. Use the key combination CTRL + SHIFT + ALT + S. A Fiori Diagnostics dialog pops up
  3. Within the dialog UI, open the Control Tree section
  4. Go back to the “General Information Basic Data” section of the Sales Order UI and press CTRL + ALT + SHIFT. Then, pick the UI section or field you are interested in within the application UI. In our example, we used the “Order Reason” field (make sure that you select the field and not its label). The control in the control tree representing this field is selected
  5. Now, you can select the “Binding Info” tab shown on the right side of the control tree screen. In the “path” field, you’ll see the name “SalesOrderManage” of the OData entity where the field is bound against (see subsequent screenshot).

Find the OData entity set name within the binding information for a field

Equipped with this information, you can now navigate back to the custom fields tool. Go to the details screen of your custom field (in our example, it’s the field “YY1_Priority”) and open the “User Interfaces” tab. Enter “SalesOrderManage” in the search bar.
This leads to the following result:

Find the OData entity set name within the binding information for a field

In the “Data Source” column, you’ll now see the “SalesOrderManageType” data source. This corresponds to the entity set name “SalesOrderManage”. The different suffix “Type” is used because in the Custom Fields app, the entity type is shown instead of the entity set name.

There may be cases where several OData services share the same OData entity set name, and all of them support exposing the respective custom fields. In this case, you can find out which of the search results is the right one by comparing the description of the OData service entry in the custom fields tool with the info you see in the “Inherited from” field within the Binding Infos tab of the control tree. Since only the technical name and not the description is shown, it won’t match exactly, but in a lot of cases it’s quite similar.

Alternatively, you can compare the names in the Custom Fields app with the ones contained in the Configuration section within Implementation Information tab of the relevant Fiori app in SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library:

OData service(s) related to Fiori app

Clicking “Enable Usage” and publishing the field makes it available for the respective UI section using Runtime Adaptation.

Variant 2: Automatic way

Please note that you can also use the integration between UI Runtime Adaptation and the custom fields tool to make this process easier:

  1. Open the Fiori app Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and navigate to the respective screen within this UI (in our case, it’s the detail screen of the sales order)
  2. Switch into Runtime Adaptation mode by selecting the “Adapt UI” option in the drop-down menu. You can get to the drop-down menu by clicking on your avatar on the top right icon representing your user
  3. Select the field or section you’re interested in. Right-click to select “+ Add: Field” from the drop-down menu
  4. A popup displays all available fields and business contexts. Mostly, there is only one – in our case it’s “Sales: Sales Document”. A “Create” option on the right top of the popup allows you to select the “Custom Field” sub-option. Clicking “Create” you’ll be navigated to the Custom Fields app. The Custom Fields app now knows from which UI section you’ve navigated to it. It also understands which OData service entity was bound against the UI section from where you came from. The business context is also taken as pre-selection information.
  5. If you create a new custom field, then the respective OData service entity is enabled automatically. If you navigate to the details of an already existing field, you’ll get a popup asking whether you want to enable the respective OData service entity you are coming from. When you select “Yes”, this will be done automatically for you (see screenshot below):

Popup allowing you to “automatically” enable the respective OData service entity for the given custom field

In case you select “No”, when you navigate back to the “User Interfaces” tab, the mentioned OData service and the OData entity will be marked with a blue bar to make it easier for you to find (see screenshot below).

OData service and OData entity marked in the Custom Fields app

Now, you’re done, and you’ve found out which OData service entity to enable to make the field available in the field list offered by Fiori Runtime Adaptation.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions:

You’re cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Also, please follow my profile to get updates when I publish more posts on these topics.
Also feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij  and Karsten Schaser for their extremely helpful contributions.

Other related blog posts and other infos:

  • https://blogs.sap.com/2022/06/23/easily-manage-your-key-user-adaptations-with-sapui5-flexibility/
  • SAP Help - Adapt UI
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-screen-personas-how-to-position-key-user-custom-fields-exactly-where/ba-p/13553723

entry.title: Help influence the next AI Features for SAP My Home on SAP S/4HANA Public Edition
entry.content:
SAP My Home is the starting point for SAP S/4HANA. It contains all your to-do items, news feeds, apps, and insights tiles and cards.  SAP Business AI delivers embedded AI capabilities that enhance user productivity through contextual to-do alerts, role-based application recommendations, and natural language-driven card creation. Additionally, Joule provides an AI-powered conversational interface to streamline information retrieval and support business operations.

We’re continuing to expand the capabilities of SAP My Home and invite your feedback on two usability-focused enhancements. To support this, we’re launching two new Customer Engagement Initiatives (CEIs), open to customers and partners using  SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Public Edition)

This initiative focuses on:

  • AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home, which provides resolution suggestions directly on the homepage for faster task completion (https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/3931)
  • AI-assisted error explanation for SAP Fiori elements-based applications, intelligent suggestions to help users fix system errors quickly and intuitively (https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/3929)

These innovations aim to reduce training time, boost productivity, and make the SAP experience more seamless and intelligent.

SAP Products in Focus

  • SAP My Home page
  • SAP Fiori apps using the SAP Fiori elements framework

Why Join?

  • Get early access to upcoming innovations
  • Help shape tools that better fit your day-to-day needs
  • Collaborate with SAP designers, developers, and product experts
  • Influence real product enhancements with your insight

Your  input now will help improve the user experience of SAP Cloud ERP, helping other customers save time and simplify business processes.

entry.title: Collective Invoicing for Service Orders Part 2: Working with Custom Fields
entry.content:
In my previous blog post, I explained the fundamentals of setting up copying control for collective invoicing in service documents. In this blog post, we will be taking a look at further steps required in case you are additionally using custom fields in your service order, for which the business scenario to copy these to billing documents have enabled, as the custom fields will act as a billing document split criteria. To suppress this, you will need to create a custom logic implementation (extension point SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER), in which you can add the following code:

 

  • Create a custom logic implementation for the extension point “SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER”

In the code editor, add the following code:

*   Mandatory step for all implementations:

*   Copy the importing parameters to the changing parameters.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc TO bil_doc_res.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item TO bil_doc_item_res.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item_contr TO bil_doc_item_contr_res.


*Clear value of custom field Ticket number, as this shouldn't be used as a split criterion for billing'

CLEAR bil_doc_res-<YY1_CUSTOM_FIELD_NAME>.
  • Define Custom Routine (SSCUI 102865):

 

In the assign enhancement IDs view, select the following. The enhancement identifier should match the filter value of the custom logic implementation from Step 1.

 

In the copy control configuration activities (from the previous blog post), for all the relevant item categories, maintain the custom routine number created in Step 2)

 

 

After this, you can test the creation of a billing document from multiple service orders to create one collective invoice, wherein the differing values of the custom field from multiple service orders will no longer act as a billing split criterion

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition seamless integration with Shopify - Complete Setup and Demo Guide
entry.content:
Tired of Juggling Data Between SAP and Shopify? We’ve Got You Covered!

Managing data and business processes across SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Shopify can often be a challenging and time-consuming task — especially when done manually or through custom-built integrations. That’s why we’re excited to introduce a ready-to-use integration package powered by SAP Integration Suite, built to simplify and streamline your operations.

Designed specifically for B2C commerce scenarios, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package ensures:

  • Seamless data synchronization between SAP and Shopify
  • Automated workflows for key business processes
  • A reduction in manual tasks and potential errors

In this blog, we’ll start with a high-level overview of what the integration offers. Then, we’ll walk you through a step-by-step guide to setting up the package — so you can get your systems connected and running efficiently with minimal effort.

Note : SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package accelerator isn’t just limited to B2C. Partners can extend the integration to support B2B use cases as well, tailoring it to fit the needs of more complex business models. The package is built with extensibility in mind, so partners can enhance it further to accommodate specific business requirements or tailor it to specific industry needs.

Overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Integration Package:

SAP provides a variety of pre-built integration accelerators via the SAP Integration Suite, all accessible through the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Among these, we’ve developed a dedicated Shopify integration accelerator that enables a seamless connection between your Shopify storefront and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

The  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package ensures real-time data consistency across both platforms by synchronizing key business objects such as:

  •  🛒  Product information
  •  📦  Inventory levels/Product Stock
  • 💲Product Prices & Discounts 
  •  👤  Customer information

By automating critical business processes like order creation, cancellations, and returns, the integration reduces manual effort, minimizes errors, and increases operational efficiency. It also synchronizes shipping and delivery details, helping you provide accurate and timely updates to customers — a key to delivering a superior B2C customer experience.

The Shopify Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud package is designed to integrate key end-to-end business processes between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Shopify, enabling smooth, automated data flow and operational consistency across both platforms.

The following core business processes are supported out of the box:

📦 From SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify:

  • ✅ Replicate Products – Ensure accurate and up-to-date product information is reflected in your Shopify storefront.
  • 📊 Replicate Product Stock – Keep inventory levels in sync to avoid overselling or stockouts.
  • 💲 Replicate Product Prices & Discounts – Automatically update pricing and promotional details in Shopify.
  • 🚚 Replicate Delivery Details – Provide timely and accurate shipping information to your customers via Shopify.

🛒From Shopify to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • 👥 Replicate B2C Customers – Capture and transfer customer data from Shopify to SAP, enabling centralized customer management.
  • 🧾Replicate Orders – Seamlessly transfer incoming sales orders into SAP for fulfillment and processing.
  • ❌ Replicate Order Cancellations – Reflect cancelled orders in SAP for proper stock and financial reconciliation.
  • 🔁 Replicate Order Returns – Automatically push return details from Shopify into SAP to streamline reverse logistics.

Together, these integration flows deliver a robust, automated B2C commerce experience, reducing manual interventions and ensuring your front-end and back-end systems remain in sync.

🚀 How to Set Up the “Shopify Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition” Package

Integrating Shopify with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is now easier than ever — thanks to the pre-built accelerator available on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This step-by-step guide will help you configure and deploy the integration package using SAP Integration Suite, so your systems can work together seamlessly.

✅Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure you have the following:

  • 🔑  An SAP Partner Account with access to SAP Integration Suite (via SAP BTP – Business Technology Platform).
  • 🧾 Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • 🛍  A Shopify Partner or Merchant Account.
  • 📘  Basic knowledge of SAP BTP, Integration Suite and Shopify. 
  • 🌐  Access to SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  • 📘Detailed Configure Guide - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 🛠️  Step 1: Set Up SAP Integration Suite instance using SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) account.

  1. Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  2. Create a Subaccount and enable Integration Suite:
    • Navigate to your Global Account > Subaccount.
    • Create or open an Integration Suite instance.
    • Assign relevant entitlements and Assign relevant roles
    • Use the Booster Enable Integration Suite to automate setup or configure manually
    • for more details refer to sap help documentation SAP Integration Suite | SAP Help Portal

📦 Step 2: Import the Shopify Adapter Package into SAP Integration Suite

  1. Goto SAP Integration Suite instance
  2. Go to Discover tab.
  3. Search for “Shopify Adapter for SAP Integration Suite”.
  • Click “Copy” to add / move the package to your Design workspace.

  • To Configure Shopify Adapter Installation - Installing the Shopify Adapter is a prerequisite to use the Integration Content. For adapter installation, refer to the “Shopify Adapter Guide” and to the “Shopify Adapter and Plug-in Installation Guide” and also refer to more details refer to section "Shopify Adapter Installation" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

🔄Step 3: Configure Shopify iFlows (Integration Flows) with API access relevant details.

  1. Go to Design > Integrations in the Integration Suite.
  2. Open the imported Shopify Integration Package.
  3. Select a relevant iFlow (e.g., Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  4. Configure the necessary Externalized Parameters and Connections, referencing the detailed documentation for each Integration Flow.
  5. To Configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - the mandatory configurations which need to be performed in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition before you can start implementing the configuration for Shopify API and configuring the Integration Content in SAP Integration Suite and for more details refer to section "Configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  6. Sample configuration shown below.

      Shopify Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • Shopify Base Url: https://<yourshop>.myshopify.com/
  • Shopify Secure Parameter: The name of the Shopify access token secure parameter 

       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Base Url: https://<your-sap-s4-hana-instance-id>-api.s4hana.cloud.sap
  • Credential Name: The name of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition secure parameter 

🧩 Example Integration Flows:

  • Shopify ➜ SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition : Customer Replication, New Orders, Order Cancellations & Returns
  • SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition ➜ Shopify: Products, Inventory Synchronization, Stock Availability, Delivery Status

🚀Step 4: Deploy and Test the Integration Package in Integration Suite

  1. Deploy selected iFlows from your Design workspace.
  2. Monitor from Monitor > Integrations > Message Processing Logs.
  3. Perform test transactions: for more details refer to Demo section in the blog
    • Place a test order in Shopify.
    • Monitor the message logs and confirm data replication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Sales Orders, Business Partners, Product Catalog

🔧 Extend or Customize the Package (Optional)

As a partner you can extend or tailor the integration through:

  • Customer Exits to plug-in your custom integration flows (Pre Exits and Post Exits in Intergration Flows)
  • Copy and modify the integration content.
  • Groovy scripts to customize payload mappings.
  • Content Modifiers to apply business logic.
  • Enhanced error handling and alerting.

 💡 Partner Tips & Monetization Opportunities

As an SAP Partner, you can:

  • 💡 Extend the integration flows and Build new integration flows using SAP Shopify adapte
  • 📜  Demo your solution with real-time order sync and inventory updates, build a demo to show real-time sync between Shopify and SAP with custom business case.
  • 🧰 Buildc Multi-Tenant Integration Templates for reuse across customers.
  • 🧠 Leverage SAP Integration Advisor for intelligent mapping.
  • 💡  Add your branding, services, or vertical-specific enhancements.

High Level Demo Flow to showcase Order processing along with Master data replication.

  • Step 1 : View the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package in Integration Suite
  • Step 2: Show product in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION  (to be replicated to shopify)
  • Step 3: Start replication of product in integration suite
  • Step 4: Show replicated product in Shopify and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product
  • Step 5: Log into shopify as customer and browse through existing products
  • Step 6: Select the product replicated from SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION and add to basket
  • Step 7: Enter the relevant details like payment and create order
  • Step 8: Check the order created in shopify
  • Step 9: Replicate the order from shopify to SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION
  • Step 10: Log into SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION as internal_sales_rep and look for “Manage Sales Order Version 2” app and open the sales order and change the order date to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Step 11: Log into SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION as shipping_specialist and open app “Create outbound delivery with order reference”
  • Step 12: Enter shipping point and enter the sales order and shipping date as todays date and save , note down the Outbound Delivery ID
  • Step 13: Open app “pick outbound delivery” and enter Outbound Delivery ID and enter Actual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter picking quantity as 1 and save
  • Step 14 : Click on Post GI and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to Completely Processed. Note : show the SO Process flow of created order in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION
  • Step 15 : Replicate the Outbound delivery from SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION public to Shopify .
  • Step 16: Open sales order in Shopify and show the OD created in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION reflected in metadata fields of Sales order and status of Sales Order is changed to fulfilled.

Detailed Demo steps:

Shopify Demo systems include the following systems - Integration Suite Tenant [along with BTP Sub-Account), SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Shopify Admin Portal, Shopify Customer Portal

Step 1:  Access the  Integration Suite tenant and view “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify” integration package

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to “Discover” -> “Integration”
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , view the integration flows and details.          

Step 2: Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition System to show the replicating product master

  • Access system using URL SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system as Product Master Specialist
  • Login with user = prodmaster_specialist
  • Launch the App : “Manage Product Master Data”  and search for Product ID  (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12)
  • Note: in the demo product replication integration flow we are replicating only one product with product ID (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12) and user could decide to replicate all products / sub-set of products, based on specific functional requirements.

Step 3: Start replication of product in Integration Suite

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Discover -> Integration (only first time)
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , open the integration package -> copy the package
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  ,
  • Navigate to “artifacts” and search for integration package “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
    • To deploy => click on the “3 dots” of integration package and select “deploy”
    • Deploy would start the product replication from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify      

Step 4: Show replicated product in Shopify and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product

  • Login using URL : Shopify 
  • Navigate to “Products”
  • Check and prepare the product for selling to customer
    • Check the product is replicated
    • Add the picture to publish (click on “Media” and click on “+” and select the relevant picture”
  • Add the sales channel as online store ( click on “Manage” in “Publishing” section, in the popup select “online store”  and click on “include” and click on “done” )
  • Set the status of the product to be “Active” and “Save” the product
  • Note: for the product to be visible for customer in shopify portal for purchasing , the status must be set to “Active” and sales channel to be set to “online store”.      

Step 5: login to shopify as customer and browse through existing products

Step 6: select the product replicated from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and add to basket

  • Purchase the product (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12)
  • Select the product from catalog
  • Click on “Add to Cart” and click on “Checkout”
  • Account and ShipTo address would be filled automatically with the logged in user details

Step 7: enter the relevant details like payment and create order

  • Enter the Credit Card Details : Card Number, Expiration Date, Security Code
  • Click on “Pay Now”  , order would be placed         

Step 8: check the order created in shopify

  • Navigate to “Orders”
  • Check the order created with fulfillment status “Unfulfilled” , note down the “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Order ID”  , order ID would be used to search order created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system      

Step 9: replicate the order from shopify to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact “Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
  • Replication of orders in status Unfulfilled would be moved to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition .
  • Note: to check the status of replication by navigating to “Monitor” => “Integration and API’s” , check for “logs”      

Step 10: Log into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system as Sales Representative

  • open for “Manage Sales Order Version 2” app
  • open the sales order and change the “Requested Delivery Date” to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Note: delivery date to be changed to today’s date, since user want to complete the delivery of the order today by creating outbound delivery today.       
     

Step 11: Log into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Delivery shipping specialist and complete the delivery of Order

  • open for “Create outbound delivery with order reference” app

Step 12: Enter the key details like Shipping Point and Sales Order ...

  • enter shipping point sample as 3810 (select shipping point relevant for your use-case) and enter the sales order ID create earlier and Selection Date would be defaulted to todays date
  • click on “continue” and click on “save”
  • note down the outbound delivery ID

Step 13: Delivery shipping specialist will pic the outbound delivery

  • open app “pick outbound delivery” and enter “Delivery” id and enter “Actual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter “picking quantity” as 1 and click on “save”         

Step 14 : Delivery shipping specialist will Post Goods Issue for the corresponding outbound delivery

  • click on “Post GI” and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to “Completely Processed”.      

Note : show the Sales Order “Process flow” of created order in SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition for the corresponding order, the process flow gives visual representation of business entities created in the system (Order, Outbound Delivery, Invoice …)

Step 15 : replicate the Outbound delivery from S4 public to Shopify .

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact “Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Delivery Details from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
  • Replication of outbound delivery from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system would be moved to Shopify and corresponding Order status would updated to “fulfilled” in Shopify
  • Note: to check the status of replication by navigating to “Monitor” => “Integration and API’s” , check for “logs”         

Step 16: open sales order in shopify and check the  status of Order, it should be changed from “Unfullfilled” to “fulfilled”

  • Navigate to “Orders”
  • With the successfully delivery , the order should be fulfilled and order status should be “Fulfilled” , note the fields “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Order ID”  and “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Outbound Deliveries”  in order would be copied from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system          

The above steps completes the High Level Demo Flow which showcase the order processing along with product master data replication.

Note: The  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package covers Order Returns and Order Cancellation business scenarios along with Order Processing, please feel free to explore the other business process like Order Returns and Order Cancellation .

entry.title: Using codelist values in custom business objects (CBO) in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In this short blog post, I would like to demonstrate how to use fields with codelist values in a Custom Business Object. For an overall introduction on how to setup the CBO, please refer to my previous blog post on the topic.

In the app “Custom Reusable Elements”, under the section “Custom Code Lists”, create a new custom code list. Enter the code values along with their respective description:

 

Once the CBO is created as per your needs, choose the type codelist for your desired field. In the codelist value, you can select the codelist created in the previous step:

Publish the CBO, and finally in the generated UI of the CBO, you can select the codelist values for your field as required:

entry.title: Controlling, Scheduling, and Costing of Production Using Custom Fields in Routing Based on AVC
entry.content:
Business Requirement 

Company X wants to calculate the production cost based on the variant selected when placing an order for a product. 

Before Company X can quote a price to its customer, it would like to know the correct cost to achieve the right profit margin. The cost calculation should occur as soon as the order is received, and well before actual production begins.

Company X applies a multiplier to the standard cost of operations, which varies depending on the product's configuration. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP.

Solution at high level
This solution will focus on calculating the production cost based on the configuration and making it visible at the sales order. It doesn't deal with sales order processes as a whole.
The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_price_factor) in Production Routing.

Key Steps in the Solution

  1. Creating Custom Field
  2. Setting Up Configurable Material
  3. Integrating Workcenter Formula
  4. Setting Object Dependency and Characteristics
  5. Executing Business Processes

Creating Custom Fields

Company X uses a custom field, YY1_price_factor, within Production Routing. This field is set up using the Key User Extensibility's Custom Field App, under the Business Context: Manufacturing Bill of Operations Operation. The custom field is crucial for linking production routing operations to sales orders.

a. Choose Add Field in the Custom Fields app.The custom field YY1_price_factor is created for production routing operations.

b. Enable the business scenario Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for the custom field YY1_price_factor.

c. Optional: Enable the GUI in the User Interface tab if you wish to see the fields in the UI.

 

Setting Up Configurable Material

a. Set the configurable material as described. The configurable material CM-MLFL-KM-VXX is associated with class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX of class type 300. Characteristics such as AVC_CR_COUNTERWEIGHT_VXX or AVC_CR_FORKLIFT_VXX are used to execute sales order variant configurations.

b. Select the UsedfVarConfig checkbox.

 

Integrating Workcenter (WKC) Formula 

a. Map the custom field YY1_price_factor to the WKC formula parameter AZMDB1 in the Define Parameters activity. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

b. Create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZMDB1 to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

For more details, see Step-by-Step Guide to Setting Up Custom Fields in Work Center Formula Parameters.

For more details on Work Center Formula, see the blog Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter.

Setting Object Dependency and Characteristics

To utilize YY1_price_factor in object dependency, it is referenced to the characteristic AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX. This characteristic is calculated using a procedure in production routing, ensuring accurate cost calculations based on configuration changes.

a. Create characteristics AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX using the Manage Characteristics app.

b. Reference the characteristic to the PLPO table with the field name YY1_price_factor_PPO in the Addnl data tab.

c. Assign characteristic AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX to class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX using the  Manage Classes app.

d. Assign the class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX to the configured material in Manage Product Master Data.

e. Create a global procedure with the characteristics AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX in production routing.

f. Maintain dependency with type Procedure.

g. Enter the formula in the Dependency Editor.

Executing Business Processes

Sales Order Impact

When a sales order is created for CM-MLFL-KM-VXX, the calculated cost and profit margin are displayed. Changes in configuration, such as altering the counterweight from 2,000 kg to 5,000 kg, dynamically adjust the costing and profit margin.

a. Set the counterweight to 2,000 kg in Variant Configuration.

The profit margin is calculated for 2,000 kgs. 

This solution focuses on calculating the production cost based on the configuration and displaying it on the sales order. It doesn't deal with sales order processes as a whole. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_price_factor) in Production Routing.

b. Set the counterweight to 5,000 kgs in Variant Configuration.The profit margin is calculated for 5,000 kgs. 

Production Order Impact

In production orders, the custom field price_factor reflects changes in sales order configurations. For instance, changing the counterweight from 2,000 kg to 5,000 kg adjusts the price_factor from 2 to 5, demonstrating the direct impact of configuration changes on production costs.

a. Search for the material CM-MLFL-KM-VXX in the Manage Material Coverage app.

 

b. Choose Start MRP Run to create a planned order.

c. Convert the planned order to a production order. Once the production order is created, check the User Field price_factor in Operations. For counterweight 2,000 KG, the price_factor is 2.

d. Now, if this counterweight is changed in the sales order variant config to 5,000 KG, and the MRP run happens again to create the production order in the same way as described above. The price_factor changes to 5 as shown below.

By integrating custom fields and formulas, Company X provides a streamlined approach to managing production costs, enhancing visibility and accuracy in sales orders and production processes. This solution empowers businesses to make informed decisions and optimize their operations.
